questiontext.text:
Example

Find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the \(3\times 3\) matrix

\[A=\begin{bmatrix} 2&-1&0\\ -1&2&-1\\ 0&-1&2\end{bmatrix}\]

Solution

The eigenvalues and eigenvectors are found by solving the eigenvalue problem

\[A\underline{x}=\lambda \underline{x} \qquad \underline{x}=\begin{bmatrix} x\\ y\\ z\end{bmatrix}\]

Proceeding as in the previous example:

\((A-\lambda I)\underline{x}=\underline{0}\)   and non-trivial solutions for \(\underline{x}\) will exist if \(\det(A-\lambda I)=0.\)

That is,

\[\det\left\{\begin{bmatrix} 2&-1&0\\ -1&2&-1\\ 0&-1&2\end{bmatrix} -\lambda\begin{bmatrix} 1&0&0\\ 0&1&0\\ 0&0&1\end{bmatrix}\right\}=0\]

i.e.,

\[\begin{vmatrix} 2-\lambda&-1&0\\ -1&2-\lambda&-1\\ 0&-1&2-\lambda\end{vmatrix}=0\]

Expanding this determinant we find:

\[(2-\lambda)\begin{vmatrix} 2-\lambda&-1\\ -1&2-\lambda\end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} -1&-1\\ 0&2-\lambda\end{vmatrix} = 0\]

that is,

\[(2-\lambda)\left\{(2-\lambda)^2-1\right\}-(2-\lambda)=0\]

Taking out the common factor \((2-\lambda)\):

\[(2-\lambda)\left\{4-4\lambda+\lambda^2-1-1\right\}\]

which gives:

\[(2-\lambda)\left[\lambda^2-4\lambda+2\right]=0.\]

This is easily solved to give \(\lambda =2\) or \(\lambda = \dfrac{4\pm \sqrt{16-8}}{2} = 2\pm \sqrt{2}\).

So (typically) we have found three possible values of \(\lambda\) for this \(3\times 3\) matrix \(A\).

To each value of \(\lambda\) there corresponds an eigenvector.

Case 1: \(\lambda = 2 - \sqrt{2}\) (lowest eigenvalue)

Then \(A\underline{x}=(2-\sqrt{2})\underline{x}\) implies

\[\left\{\begin{alignedat}{3} 2x & {}-{} & y & & & = (2 - \sqrt{2})x \\ -x & {}+{} & 2y & {}-{} & z & = (2 - \sqrt{2})y \\ & & -y & {}+{} & 2z & = (2 - \sqrt{2})z \end{alignedat}\right.\]

Simplifying,

\begin{alignat}{3} \sqrt{2}x & {}-{} & y & & & = 0 \tag{a} \\ -x & {}+{} & \sqrt{2}y & {}-{} & z & = 0 \tag{b} \\ & & -y & {}+{} & \sqrt{2}z &= 0 \tag{c} \end{alignat}

We conclude the following:

\[\text{(c)} \implies y = \sqrt{2}z \qquad \text{(a)} \implies y = \sqrt{2}x\]

These two relations give \(x=z\), then \(\text{(b)} \implies -x+2x-x=0\).

The last equation gives us no information; it simply states that \(0=0\).

Therefore, \(\underline{x}=\begin{bmatrix} x\\ \sqrt{2}x\\ x\end{bmatrix}) for any \(x\neq 0\) (otherwise we would have the trivial solution). So the eigenvectors corresponding to eigenvalue \(\lambda =2-\sqrt{2}\) are all proportional to \(\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ \sqrt{2}\\ 1\end{bmatrix}\).

In normalised form we have an eigenvector \(\dfrac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\\sqrt{2}\\ 1\end{array}\right].\)

Case 2: \(\lambda = 2\)

Here \(A\underline{x}=2\underline{x}\) implies

\[\left[\begin{array}{rrr}2&-1&0\\ -1&2&-1\\ 0&-1&2\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}x\\ y\\ z\end{array}\right]=2\left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ y\\ z\end{array}\right]\]

i.e.,

\[\left\{\begin{alignedat}{3} 2x & {}-{} & y & & & = 2x \\ -x & {}+{} & 2y & {}-{} & z & = 2y \\ & & -y & {}+{} & 2z & = 2z \end{alignedat}\right.\]

After simplifying the equations become:

\begin{alignat}{3} & & -y & & &= 0 \tag{a} \\ -x & & & {}-{} & z &= 0 \tag{b} \\ & & -y & & & = 0 \tag{c} \end{alignat}

\(\text{(a)}\) and \(\text{(c)}\) imply \(y=0\), while \(\text{(b)}\) implies \(x=-z\).

Therefore, the eigenvectors have the form \(\left[\begin{array}{r}x\\0\\-x\end{array}\right]\) for any \(x\ne 0\).

That is, eigenvectors corresponding to \(\lambda=2\) are all proportional to \(\left[\begin{array}{r}1\\0\\-1\end{array}\right]\).

In normalised form we have an eigenvector \(\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\begin{array}{r}1\\0\\-1\end{array}\right]\).

Case 3: \(\lambda = 2 + \sqrt{2}\) (largest eigenvalue)

Proceeding along similar lines to cases 1 and 2 above we find that the eigenvectors corresponding to \(\lambda=2+\sqrt{2}\) are each proportional to \(\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\-\sqrt{2}\\ 1\end{array}\right]\) with normalised eigenvector \(\dfrac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\ -\sqrt{2}\\ 1\end{array}\right]\).

In conclusion, the matrix \(A %=\left[\begin{array}{rrr}2&-1&0\\ -1&2&-1\\ %0&-1&2\end{array}\right]\) has three distinct eigenvalues:

\[\lambda_1=2-\sqrt{2},\qquad \lambda_2=2\qquad \lambda_3=2+\sqrt{2}\]

and three corresponding normalised eigenvectors:

\[\underline{x}_1=\dfrac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\ \sqrt{2}\\ 1\end{array}\right],\qquad \underline{x}_2=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\begin{array}{r}1\\ 0\\-1\end{array}\right],\qquad \underline{x}_3=\dfrac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\-\sqrt{2}\\ 1\end{array}\right]\]

Note that even when normalised we have a choice of vector, namely \(\underline{v}\) and \(-\underline{v}\).
